PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the fact that at a time when his Department was making an intensive probe into alleged social security breaches by one ethnic community it was disclosed by the New South Wales Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking that a man named Bonetti made thousands of dollars out of criminal activities and was still drawing social security cheques. Has there been a probe on Bonetti to see that he repays the money he wrongly received?

—The particular case is not one that is known to me, I regret to say. I think the man in question may have been named before my time as Minister. In any event it is not a matter of which I have any direct personal knowledge, nor do I appear to have any advice on it in the brief which I have. But bearing in mind the personal nature of the inquiry, that is not surprising. I will make inquiries and let the honourable senator have a reply as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the sake of the Minister's and my own credibility, I reinforce my question and ask him whether he is aware that the man who made that assertion was the Sydney ace crime investigator, Bob Bottom.
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Could the Minister please advise as to the possibility of this Government questioning the authorities in Guatemala on the disappearance of 70 Guatemalan politicians between January 1980 and January 1982 as reported in that country's printed media? I ask this question in the light of the fact that Amnesty International has been unsuccessful in its attempts to investigate these disappearances and an approach from the Australian Government to the Guatemalan authorities on this matter could prove to be of assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Foreign Affairs has received letters about the killing and disappearance of politicians in Guatemala. This is a matter of deep concern to the Government, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs has asked the Australian Ambassador in Mexico City, who is also accredited to Guatemala, to make representations to the Guatemalan Government and to try to obtain further information about this matter. To date no further information has been received by the Foreign Minister but as soon as a report is sent from the Ambassador I will see that Senator Bjelke-Petersen is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Was it announced in June 1981 that a Special Broadcasting Service ethnic advisory committee would be established by the Government under the chairmanship of Mr Frank Galbally? Has that committee yet been appointed? Is the Mr Galbally the same Mr Galbally who was referred to en passant in chapter 6 of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? What is the reason, if that committee has not been appointed, why it has not been appointed?
—It is clearly desirable that I seek detailed answers from the Minister for Communications and that I will undertake to do.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, concerns a matter that I think will be of public interest, or at least of interest to those very many sporting people who reside in this country, that is, the code of conduct for the Commonwealth Games that Australia is being asked to sign. I must say that I have had difficulty in obtaining a copy of that document although it may well be shown to me during the day. Has the Minister seen the document? Is it true that the New Zealand Commonwealth Games Committee has refused to sign the code because it feels that to do so would be overstepping its authority as it says the code applies to sportsfolk outside its jurisdiction? Is it true that, if the Australian Commonwealth Games Committee signs that code, it may well be to the detriment of many sporting Australians? Why should such a group-indeed any group -be able to dictate to other sportspeople? Will the Minister arrange for the code to be released to the public so that we can have some discussion of the issues and so on that may result from the signing by Australia, behind closed doors, of a code that may well be used to apply pressures to people who in no way are involved in the Commonwealth Games?

—Senator Townley's question really rests on whether the document to which he referred is available to me and whether I have seen it. Since I have not seen the document, I really cannot be aware of the answers to his subsequent questions, important though they are and desirable as answers may be. It is appropriate, therefore, that I ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment whether he has the document in question, if he does not have it whether he can obtain it, and whether he can then answer the questions put by Senator Townley, including the request that the document be released for more public scrutiny. I undertake so to do.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the event of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill being passed by this Parliament, will a student who repays a student loan after graduation be able to claim either loan repayments or interest payments as income tax deductions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether that matter has been addressed by the Treasurer up to this point. I will check with him. This matter would have to be considered after the legislation is passed, in terms of deductibility in respect of income tax. I do not know that that matter has had consideration at this point, but I will check that for Senator Colston.

—My question is ad- dressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. When will the extended terms of reference concerning the Nugan Hand bank for the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking be finalised and made available to the Commission and the Parliament? Why have the terms of reference been delayed since the Government's April 1982 announcement that they would be extended? Have any of the State governments delayed the consideration of the extended terms of reference? If so, which governments are they and why have these delays occurred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that, by the end of Question Time, I will be able to provide specific answers. I do not have those specific answers at the moment. In generality, it was through the actions of this Government that the Stewart Royal Commission and the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs were set up. It is the desire of this Government that all such pursuits of investigations, including the pursuit of Nugan Hand, should be carried out to the full. I want to make that absolutely clear without any qualification. Immediately I will seek to find out whether there has been any undue delay and any particular attitude of a State government. As soon as I can, I will let the honourable senator have a reply.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General been drawn to a Press report that the Queensland Government has freed a student and withdrawn a serious criminal charge following intervention by the Yemen and Australian governments? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement of the Queensland Minister for Justice and Attorney-General that a charge of unlawful wounding against Saeed Abdo Mahfood from South Yemen has been dropped following approaches to the Queensland Cabinet by Canberra? Did the Attorney-General's Department or any other department make an approach to the Queensland Government for the release of the student? Did the Attorney-General's Department or any other department request that the charges against the student be dropped? If any intervention took place, will the Minister outline any other details in regard to this matter?
—I have not seen the report referred to by the honourable senator. I will ask the Acting Attorney-General to give me a reply to the series of questions raised by the honourable senator.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review which drew attention to the possibility at the moment or in the immediate future of a reduction in iron ore and coal exports to Japan. Has the Leader seen the article, particularly the passage in the article that says that union unreliability, particularly in the iron ore industry, is not essentially a cause of the potential drop in exports? Has the Leader ever seen, as I have over many years, large queues of iron ore carriers off Port Hedland? Does he agree with the article? My experience is that union unreliability must be a cause of a drop in exports. Does the Leader find the statement on this matter in the Australian Financial Review hard to accept?
—Order! The honourable senator will finish his question.

—Has the Leader considered that perhaps bigger ports are necessary in both Queensland and Western Australia to enable Australia more competitively to offer its products to the Japanese and to any other markets which may be available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw an article in the Australian Financial Review yesterday relating to the fall in exports to Japan of iron ore and coal. It is, of course, a matter of judgment and not precision as to how much of the fall is due to shrinking markets around the world. I indicated yesterday the excess steel capacity of the free world. However, I can say emphatically to Senator Martyr that in a series of discussions in the past year at ministerial level both here and in Japan I have been told a number of times by the Japanese of their concern about industrial troubles and port delays in Australia. The Japanese Ministers have expressed the greatest concern about the necessity for any contracts that are made and maintained to be based upon the absolute reliability of the supplier as in normal times the ore goes from port to ship to port and then to mills literally in a 24-hour timetable situation.

ANSWER.PARA: At all the ministerial discussions, particularly the discussions with individual Ministers, the reliability of Australia has been raised and argued with us. The concern in relation to industrial matters has been stressed to us, as have worries about the inadequacy of coal ports and loading ports. Of course, the queues of ships off New South Wales have been disastrous in terms of exports in recent times. The simple fact is that, whatever may be the judgment as to how much has been caused by the recession and how much has been caused by our unreliability as a trader, in looking to the future Australia must be able, if it wants to be accepted as a reliable partner in the world, to put aside its industrial conflicts and to unbutton the bottlenecks at the ports and loading zones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the Leader might like to comment further on the necessity for new ports that will carry much larger quantities.
—He missed the point of the question. That is what it was all about.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question related to industrial conflict, as Hansard will show. I made the point that along with the question of industrial confict there was the problem of ports, of facilities for loading and for handling, and of infrastructure. That has been stressed to us. Of course, quite clearly the need for the development of better infrastructure, particularly at ports, is one of the factors which would create a disability for the future should things look up and contracts wish to expand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It is a question of some detail, but important detail, on an item that appeared at page 359 of the United States Nuclear Proliferation Factbook of September 1980. The item is in the section devoted to United States nuclear weapons incidents. One could almost substitute the word 'accidents' for ' incidents' but it is headed 'incidents'. On that page it states that on 16 and 17 June 1968 a weapons system was aboard the United States cruiser Boston and the Australian destroyer Hobart. The place is listed as 'off Vietnam, Tonkin Gulf', and the source is shown as '23-24'. The incident is stated as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: United States plane or planes (believed to be F4 Phantom) sank a United States patrol boat and carried out accidental missile attacks against United States cruiser Boston--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I suggest, Senator, that you are giving a terrific amount of information for a question?

—I realise that. I am coming to the end of it now. I seek the indulgence of yourself and the Senate. The United States plane made an accidental attack on the Australian guided missile destroyer Hobart. The report continues:

QUESTION.PARA: Boston and Hobart carry Terrier, a surface-to-air missile with a nuclear warhead .

I ask the Minister: Can he confirm that this is an erroneous statement? Has the Government taken or will it take appropriate steps to correct this error by the United States Government? I realise that the Minister may not have the answer at his fingertips; but, if he can get it from the Minister for Defence before the end of Question Time, I will be grateful.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it happens, I do have some information on the matter but it is of only the very broadest kind. I can confirm that the main point of Senator Chipp's remarks in connection with the nuclear warheaded Terrier missile is erroneous and that in fact Hobart was not carrying that weapon. As to obtaining a correction of the statement, that is a matter that I will need to refer to the Minister and I undertake to do that.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that Griffith University has adjusted its academic year to enable the university's facilities to be used for the Commonwealth Games? Will there be any consequences for the payment of educational allowances to Griffith University students who may complete their academic program earlier than usual in 1982 because of the Games?

—Honourable senators will be aware that Griffith University is the site of some of the facilities, in particular, residential facilities, that will be used for the Games. I can understand Senator Martin's concern that students may experience some disruption as a result of the need to adjust the academic year. The teaching year at Griffith has been rearranged to take account of interruptions in September and October. It will consist of two semesters, each of three months, before the Games and will be followed by a period of assessment after the Games. That may go on until a little later than normal. Students at the university who qualify for allowances under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme for 1982 will, in fact, subject to normal conditions , receive those allowances in full to 31 December. Therefore, although the academic year of the university will have to be adjusted to take account of the Games and to allow participants to use the facilities that have been provided, there will be no adverse consequences for students in terms of TEAS allowances. Nor will there be any disadvantage to students in this regard as a consequence of the teaching year being interrupted.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether the Prime Minister consulted with the Victorian State Government before tabling the synopsis of the unpublished Costigan report. If he did not, what explanation can the Minister provide for the Prime Minister's action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My instinct is that there was such consultation. The Costigan Royal Commission was set up by the present Federal Government and the previous State Liberal Government as a joint venture. Therefore, the report and its management is a joint matter. My understanding is that such consultation occurred but I will seek confirmation as soon as possible and inform Senator Robert Ray.

—I preface my question, which is addressed to the Minister for Education, by referring to an article which appeared in the National Times of 12 September and in which it was alleged that the White Cliffs solar power experiment is a failure. White Cliffs is a small opal town in New South Wales with a total population of about 10 families. The article alleges that the Australian National University's Research School of Physical Sciences in Canberra was involved in that project. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the ANU is interested in the project? If so, what have been the costs of this research to this point? Further, if it is continuing at the university's School of Physical Sciences, what are the costs to the school?
—I will try to obtain that information for the honourable senator, who represents New South Wales, as I do, and therefore represents the town of White Cliffs. It is part of his electorate.
—Have you ever been there? I have.

—I wonder whether Senator Douglas McClelland has ever been to Tibooburra. I remember the last time I was in that town, which is also in my electorate. Perhaps we share the experience. I well recall the introduction of the solar power experiment at White Cliffs. The reasoning behind it was that a small self-contained community was the place for such a project to be tested, and White Cliffs lent itself to that purpose. It received some publicity at the time. I am not able to advise Senator Lajovic whether the financial details of the project are as he has stated but I will try to obtain that information for him. I would be very concerned if the project had been a failure-if the experiment in solar power generation had not led to the energy savings or efficiencies which had been postulated. I would be particularly concerned if cost factors had contributed to such a failure. I will undertake to seek that information.

—My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate follows the question asked by Senator Martyr and the Minister's reply. Has the Minister seen the front page article in the Australian of 7 September in which Mr Bruce Watson, the managing director of MIM Holdings Ltd, stated that the country's industrial relations problems are often over-stated and 'are not about to lead to anarchy'? Did he see in the same article where the chairman of the Shell group in Australia, Mr Kevan Gosper, is reported to have said that the country did itself a great deal of disadvantage by continually hawking its industrial problems and that management must take a lot of the responsibility for that? Does the Minister consider these two views to be reasonable and, if so, when his colleagues and the media next become involved in blaming the trade union movement for Australia's ailing economy will he remind them that fact should be separated from sensationalism in the field of industrial relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very happy to convey to the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, the symptoms that Senator McIntosh has just expressed because Mr Wran, uniquely, has been most strenuous in his attack upon elements of the trade union movement for holding the whole of New South Wales and other parts of Australia to ransom. One should not be selective. Right at this moment Australia is experiencing a most serious, crippling strike and emergency legislation has had to be introduced to give directions to break through a bottleneck of a group of trade unionists. Against that background I think Senator McIntosh's question comes uncommonly badly timed.
—I am talking about overseas and what MIM said.

—I direct myself to that. I said before that the Japanese had raised at each of the recent ministerial meetings the question of industrial relations in Australia. I did not say that all the blame should be laid at the feet of the trade union movement. I make that perfectly clear. I believe that the polarisation of conflict between management and worker in this country is ugly and totally unnecessary. I have always said that and I have never been in a situation in which I would level blame in that regard in a polarised way. Until management and worker come to an understanding that they have a common interest and not a civil war this country will suffer continuously.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen a number of reports and I believe what Senator McIntosh says is accurate. Both those people said that there is presented to the outside world an exaggeration of our industrial strife in comparison with other countries. I have argued that very strongly on the international scene, and so have other Ministers. I have argued to the Japanese and I have argued to the Europeans that, whilst we are not without blame in our industrial situation, we sit unhappily at about the middle in the world based on our industrial conflict performance. I do not want to say that my response to the question by Senator Martyr on Western Australia was aimed at any one target. I aimed to say that the world outside, those who buy our products, are very concerned that we should be reliable partners. They are concerned that we have the infrastructure to supply the things they need and a little reflection on the matter will remind Senator McIntosh that that is what I said.

I would be very happy indeed to work with anyone who would seek to minimise the conflict that lies in industry, and that is what the Government is trying to do. The Government is trying to see, through the very great benefits provided in the present Budget and through consultations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employer organisations, that it can come to a better understanding. I hope that in the longer run we reach a bipartisan situation in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Is the Minister aware of fears expressed by some tertiary students' representatives that the criteria for qualifying for loans under the new loans scheme will have the effect of discriminating against women, students from low income families and part time students? Since the Government has stated that the loans scheme is intended to assist financially disadvantaged students, what safeguards does the Government have in mind to prevent the effects to which I have referred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The loans scheme which has been proposed by the Government will give very considerable benefit to students, and because of the means test, which is the threshold test, the benefits will be directed towards the less well -off students. The scheme which has been announced, with its very generous rate of interest subsidy and its loan repayment holiday, will benefit students who take advantage of it. As the honourable senator will know, the Government has proposed that the interest rates payable by students will be 5 per cent less than the ruling overdraft interest rate. This would be a very preferential rate of interest for those students who take loans.

ANSWER.PARA: I have heard expressions of some fears from student representatives, and indeed I received a delegation yesterday, as did some other senators. The only tests which are being applied are income tests and the test that students should be full time students. It has never been intended that the scheme should be made available for part time students. It is for full time students who are needy. The proposal will add a further benefit and a further option to those undertaking tertiary education. Because it offers an extra benefit and an extra option, it is something which I hope the student community will welcome. Because it is optional, it is entirely up to students whether they use it, but it is generous and it carries no risks for students who may wish to take advantage of the scheme.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Colston

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I did not want to interrupt the Minister, so I did not take this point of order whilst he was replying. I refer you to Standing Order 99 which says, among other things:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions shall not refer to debates in the current session.

The matter of student loans is in its second reading stage at present. I do not know whether Standing Order 99 would tie that question to that debate, but I should like to ask for a ruling from you so that we may be clear as to future questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The anticipation rule within Standing Order 99 is not held in the strictness of the language, the reason being that, if that were so, it would restrict Question Time so much because of so many things being on notice papers that we would never have a Question Time. This has been the practice of the Senate for many years.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the decision by the Returned Services League that will in future allow Australians who fought in the Rhodesian Army to become members of the RSL? Does this decision apply to those members of the Rhodesian Army who served after the unilateral declaration of independence by the Smith Government? Does it also include those Australians who fought as mercenaries with the Smith forces against the Patriotic Front forces of Joshua Nkomo and Robert Mugabe?

—Even though I represent the Department of Veterans' Affairs in this place, I am certainly not responsible for the actions of the Returned Services League. As to the point that has now been made about certain decisions taken on membership of the RSL, that is something on which I have no immediate information. I shall make some inquiries for Senator Sibraa as to the decision which may or may not have been made in this regard and correspond with him directly.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer the Minister to departmental advice that I have received that some television receiving systems which are being offered for sale in remote communities in the Northern Territory will not be issued with a licence by the Department because they do not carry the UHF band. These systems have already been sold at considerable cost to some Aboriginal communities and outback cattle stations. Can the Minister indicate what measures, if any, can be taken to acquaint communities with licensing requirements and at the same time safeguard them against the purchase of wrong receivers? Will the Minister consider preparing a comprehensive paper indicating the present situation in regard to television satellite reception in the outback as this would help to clear up much existing confusion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand this is a problem in some remote communities, but I must advise Senator Kilgariff that the Department of Communications does not license television receivers and therefore may not have a direct role to play. I understand that the matter is being brought to the attention of the relevant Minister and to the Government of the Northern Territory in case there is something that they wish to do within their legislative responsibility. In May of this year the Minister for Communications issued a Press release in which he drew attention to the disabilities which may occur if people continue to disadvantage themselves by purchasing television receivers which are not equipped with UHF capabilities, as Senator Kilgariff pointed out in his question .

ANSWER.PARA: For some years now the Department has been trying to encourage importers and manufacturers of television sets to produce receivers of an appropriate quality and capacity. But it is very difficult to know the extent to which the Minister for Communications can, in fact, direct or control what is made available within the market to consumers. The Minister is concerned by rumours that some cheap receivers not equipped with UHF capability are being sold, particularly in the Northern Territory. I suggest, however, that reference to the Northern Territory Government and to the agencies of that Government may be the most direct way in which to resolve the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows the answer he gave to Senator McIntosh on the problems this country is facing in industrial relations. He said, I believe, that Australia is in 'deep trouble' unless we can minimise the conflict in industry and stop the war between management and the trade union movement. Some little time ago the Senate passed the Industrial Democracy Bill which was designed to do just that; that is, to minimise the conflict. It incorporated, amongst other things, three important initiatives which, at the time, had the full backing of the trade union movement. I refer to employee share ownership, consultative councils--
—Order! I suggest that you ask your question. You are again giving a lot of information.
—I am coming right to the question, Mr President. I ask: Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate tell us what progress is being made in the other place with the Industrial Democracy Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware of the Bill and I accept that Senator Siddons in introducing it had as his goal, as indeed I hope we all have, a methodology for bringing about industrial peace with equity for both sides. There are great discussions in all fields as to the terms and conditions under which industrial peace and industrial democracy, if I may use that phrase, can be achieved. Therefore, the Government is having a considerable number of discussions at various levels at the moment. It will have taken note of the intentions within Senator Siddons's Bill. I am not aware of the actual progress of the Bill. However, I stress that the kinds of arguments that are put forward to achieve industrial peace certainly will be taken into account. Whether the Government would consider that the Bill was the desirable instrument is a matter of judgment for the Government and another place. I will check up and see what progress has been made.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the decision of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to stand down some 2,500 workers in New South Wales and its warning that further retrenchments could be on the cards at Whyalla in South Australia. Is the Minister aware that one of the reasons given for these latest retrenchments is the unacceptably high level of steel imports? Does this not contradict the statement made by the Prime Minister on 27 August that the Government's decision not to restrict the level of steel imports would not create unemployment in the industry? Does the Minister not agree that a continuing high level of steel imports, coupled with a shrinking domestic market for steel, has contributed to the pressure on BHP to reduce its production and hence its work force? Will the Government urgently reconsider its decision not to limit steel imports in view of the worsening unemployment situation not only in the steel industry but also throughout the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised by the honourable senator is one about which a number of statements have required correction over recent days. There is, of course, a great deal of concern about the state of the steel industry in Australia. That concern was reflected, I think, at the meeting which was held yesterday between the Government and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. Mr Short was in Canberra with other officers of that union. As no doubt the honourable senator is aware, there was agreement that a steel industry council should be established which would have a role in determining the longer term level of assistance and protection for the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the recent retrenchments are concerned, however, I refer the honourable senator to the Press release which was put out by the Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce on 14 September. The Press release followed an announcement which came from BHP linking the retrenchments to the Government's decision. Mr Fife pointed out that he in fact had received an assurance from the management of BHP that the announcement of retrenchments was not in any way the result of the Government's temporary assistance decision. The simple fact which underlies that statement is that, as Mr Fife was informed by the company, the products subject to temporary assistance were not produced at the steelworks in Newcastle which is the works at which the retrenchments occurred.

The matter is not just a straightforward one of saying that if we granted some additional temporary protection, as requested, the retrenchments would not have occurred because the request did not relate to the sort of steel which is produced in the area where the retrenchments occurred. There are difficulties in the steel industry but it is not the view of the Government that those difficulties will be met simply by applying protective provisions. The matter is before the appropriate authorities for inquiry at the moment. The matter will be watched very carefully by the Government as this, of course, is a very significant industry for Australia. Clearly it is being watched very carefully by the relevant trade unions which are concerned. The matter no doubt will be the subject of discussion and announcement from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It relates to youth unemployment. I ask: Is the Minister aware of a scheme proposed by the British Secretary of State for Employment who believes that young people in Britain are unemployed because they are pricing themselves out of jobs? He thinks they may be able to gain experience and enter the labour market by accepting very low wages for a beginning. I ask whether the Australian Government is giving any consideration to any scheme of this type? Is it giving consideration to an attack on the problems of youth unemployment by allowing them, for example, to work on a hourly basis; by encouraging them to work a shorter week which they may be better able to handle, such as 20 or 30 hours; and by breaking the strangling consequences of minimum wage provisions for 16 and 17-year-olds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not part of the Government's programs to tackle the very serious question of youth unemployment by arranging either reduced hours or reduced pay in that sector. I think it would be common ground around the chamber that the price of labour does have a very significant effect on the demand for labour and it is undoubtedly true that the cost or the award rates applying to young and inexperienced workers may well be at a level where the employment of such workers is simply not economic. The Government's response to that has been not to seek the lowering of those award wages in its tackling of this problem to date. Rather, it has provided a series of subsidies to employers which, of course, have the effect of reducing the cost of labour to the level at which it is to the economic advantage of the employer to employ. One achieves the same result but, of course, at very considerable cost to the taxpayer.

ANSWER.PARA: There are very significant subsidies with respect to a great number of apprentices employed in Australia through the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme. There is the Special Youth Employment Training Program. Subsidies are available for unemployed youth who have been out of work for some time. In the recent Budget there was a considerable expansion of those programs in money terms and also, as I recall, some liberalisation of the administration with the view to giving the eligible young unemployed the opportunity of looking for employment virtually armed with a commitment that they would be eligible for the subsidy. The Commonwealth Government has responded to the problem that is raised by the honourable senator in his question by subsidy rather than by seeking employment at reduced rates.

There is no area in which one is more likely to get suggestions for change than this because there is widespread community concern about unemployed youth. All honourable senators, I am sure, receive representations which suggest, for example, that those receiving unemployment benefit might be asked to provide some service for it. That is a suggestion which has been raised frequently. Many proposals are put forward. I merely wish to say to the Senate that the Government has tried to approach the problems of unemployed youth in a coherent fashion. It has looked at the education area, which is the responsibility of Senator Baume, and has tried to ensure that the allowances available for both secondary students and tertiary students are available at a level, and to people on such incomes, which will ensure that education remains a viable option for the great bulk of young people. I think two-thirds of the 15, 16 and 17-year- olds in Australia remain in education. We have looked to the subsidisation of employment and we have looked to improving the resources available to those who work with unemployed and homeless youth.

I thank the honourable senator for the suggestion which is contained in his question. I will ensure that it is drawn to the attention of Mr Macphee and that it is taken into account in the continuing consideration which we three Ministers in particular give to the problems of people in this particular age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. TALK.START.PARA: —The question asked today by Senator Button, the question asked yesterday by Senator Evans and the statement by Senator Evans this morning are a little strange in light of the fact that the Government has in fact taken substantial action in this area. I have no particulars of the advice supplied by the Attorney-General's Department in the course of preparing for the action which was taken, but I refer both honourable senators who have raised this matter to the Treasurer's statement of 11 May 1982, which deals in considerable detail with the question of trust stripping.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 4 December 1980 any person who enters into an arrangement for the purpose of securing that a trustee will be unable to pay the trust's income tax liability has been liable to prosecution under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. In other words, such persons are subject to severe criminal penalty. If Senator Evans has evidence that in fact those procedures are still being used, certainly he should draw any such evidence to the attention of the Commissioner of Taxation or the Government, as he would wish-the Commissioner is the person responsible-because it would appear that criminal offences are being committed. That is something which would be of very great concern to the Government. The advice which is available to the Government-I quote here from information provided by the Treasurer to my colleague who represents the Treasurer in this place, in response to the query which was made by Senator Evans-is that in fact the practice is at an end. It is a practice which on our advice is not currently proceeding. But, as I said before, if there is any evidence to the contrary we would certainly wish to know about it.

The other thing is that the Treasurer announced in the statement I have mentioned that, if there was any deficiency in the law with respect to dealing with these schemes, the Government would legislate back to that date to correct the law. In other words, the Government has put on the public record that it is prepared to legislate back to that date of announcement if some technical reason requires it. There is no technical reason known to the Government; but, if it emerged that there was, the Government would legislate to catch the practice. Whilst I cannot respond by saying what advice has been given by the Attorney- General's Department-I will have to take that part of the question on notice-I can say that this matter has been attended to, that the practice is one which carries very significant criminal penalties and that the advice we have is that the practice is one which has effectively been terminated but that, should that not be the case, we would wish to have any information which is available to the Opposition so that it can be attended to.

I wish first to voice my disappointment that this annual report arrived the day after the estimates for the Public Service Board had been considered by the relevant Estimates Committee. It is a fairly well printed document and I see no reason why it could not have been available to Committee members to peruse before we looked at the Estimates. That it arrived the day after is a matter for regret.

I wish to comment on one or two aspects of the report. The first relates to the staff ceilings. The Board notes with pride that over a period of a year there has been a 1.6 per cent reduction in the staff employed in the Public Service. When, at the Estimates Committee hearings, you ask the various heads of departments or assistant secretaries of departments whether these staff reductions are affecting their efficiency the answer is always that they are not . If, in fact, the departments are below establishment level and their representatives are asked, 'If you are operating efficiently, why should you go up to your establishment level?', you rarely receive an answer that is convincing.

I believe we can see already in two areas, those of the Australian Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Office, the problems that have been caused by these staff reductions. Reductions in the staffing of certain departments have been penny wise and pound foolish. That was seen last year in respect of the Taxation Office, concerning which it was suggested that some 140 jobs in the enforcement and prosecution section might go by the board. However, it was estimated that $45m would then have been lost to Consolidated Revenue, compared with a proposed saving of $1.5m. The second aspect of the report is that the Public Service Board, as does every other section of the Public Service, uses consultants. Everywhere we look in Estimates figures or annual reports we find that these bodies are employing consultants at very high rates of pay. I wonder why an organisation such as the Public Service Board cannot obtain expertise from within its own ranks to carry out some of the studies that are undertaken. It is a specialist body, expert in systems of administration and how departments should be run. For the life of me, I cannot see why so many consultants are needed.
Another aspect of the report with which I strongly disagree concerns page 6 where, under the heading of 'Industrial action in the Service', the Board makes the following comment:
The Board reiterates its conviction that industrial action by public servants cannot be justified and in the longer term can only prove damaging to the Service.

That is a fairly bald statement. I do not mind the Public Service Board criticising in its reports specific industrial actions and backing up that criticism with whatever evidence it can adduce. What I do object to is the Board making the statement that it believes that any industrial action by public servants is, ipso facto, wrong. We all know that without some sort of industrial protection by unions in the Public Service this Government would make public servants the pacesetters in the community-that is, the downward pacesetters, the ones whose salaries would be reduced to set the example to the rest of the community. It is wrong for an annual report to contain such a slur against the unions.

I also think that the Public Service Board should have a look at the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It came out in the Department's annual report , published a couple of weeks ago, that there has been a 31.9 per cent turnover in its core staff. I do not know of any other area that has had a 31.9 per cent turnover in core staff. It seems to be a matter of pride for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that that occurred. I can understand that there is a need for interchange of employment to get wider experience but I would have thought that a turnover of almost a third is far too great. The only other comment I wish to make is that the Board has reported on a devolution of the recruitment function by the Board. That is commendable. It has noted that it will be under regular audit and review, and this is one of the major steps mentioned in the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I appreciate the scrupulousness of the Institute in that regard but the point is that because of the gap left by the lack of sponsorship by such companies the Government has added responsibilities. As to the recruitment of potential stars in the various sports, one of the greatest difficulties is that many people who have been on the verge of Olympic selection have gone through the intensity of hard training up to the time they are 20 years old, but if they are rated only fifth or sixth they do not make the Olympic Games team, although their educational objectives have often suffered. I say that because I am pleased that Don Talbot has been reappointed. Obviously the performances of some Olympic stars are forgotten after a couple of years, and in the competitive world they find that often it is difficult to get a job commensurate with their abilities.

I go beyond that. I suppose that we were once a country in which there were cricket and the various football codes and none of the other sports meant very much. People such as Raelene Boyle have been unfairly criticised in some areas. As members of this place will know-I pay tribute to Senator Missen, who is not present; and Senator Martyr should not take offence at that-we took up the cause of Gael Mulhall over the unfair imposition in relation to breaches of particular amateur procedures. Much as we say that sport is above politics, the plain fact is that at the time-her case exemplified it-the Third World countries wanted to get even with the United States through one of their athletes, and Gael Mulhall found herself an innocent victim of the crossfire. Australia must maintain a fairly solid standard. When our athletes are unfairly stigmatised, we must stand up for them.

I must throw one brickbat. I refer to the South Australian Minister who was responsible for Home Affairs before the changes to the Ministry. When I raised the question of Gael Mulhall's unfair treatment with him, he lectured me in a letter by saying that this Government does not interfere in sport. The broad comment one can make about the whole memorandum of understanding concerning financing of the Northern Territory since 1978 is that there has been a reasonable approach to it and the Northern Territory is getting assistance from the Federal Government. I used the word 'reasonable' because we have just finished an examination of the estimates of the Department of the Capital Territory and it will be known that I have been reasonably critical of the amount of money which has been made available to the Australian Capital Territory over the years. It is obvious that the Northern Territory still remains very much the poor cousin in relation to the amount of money that is provided to the Australian Capital Territory.

Under the memorandum of understanding the Northern Territory does receive extra money in place of the Grants Commission allocation. It started at $20m and is going down at the rate of $5m a year. Obviously at some time in the future there will be nothing available to the Northern Territory by way of this special grant and the Northern Territory will be looking to the Grants Commission for assistance with projects in the Northern Territory. In order to do that-of course, the Grants Commission is already doing it-the Grants Commission must assess the ability of the Northern Territory to raise revenue. I ask the Grants Commission to note that the capacity of the Northern Territory in this matter is particularly limited, basically for two reasons: Firstly, the small tax base of the Northern Territory and, secondly, the high cost structure.

I deal first with the small tax base. The Northern Territory has a population of only 130,000 and this includes many who are not in receipt of any wages. There is a high rate of unemployment in the Northern Territory and there is no indication at the present time that the employment situation will improve in the foreseeable future. Approximately 25 per cent of the Northern Territory's population are Aboriginal people. Many of those people live in areas where there is no possibility of employment. It is not a case of their not wanting to work; there is no possibility of employment because there are no industries in many of these areas. It is fair to say that in some of the areas there is a little possibility of industry developing at the present time.

I remind the Federal Government that it encouraged the development of self- government in the Northern Territory, as we all did. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I present the fifth and sixth general reports of the Committee together with the transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.

The Committee's fifth report brings together and makes final recommendations on many of the matters covered in the first four reports presented. In particular the Committee has focused on the following issues: The circumstances in which authorities should be created; the degree of operating independence which should be granted to authorities; recommendations for an effective system of accountability for authorities; and categorisation of authorities for accountability purposes

The report contains a categorised list of authorities which updates the list contained in earlier reports and incorporates changes suggested by particular authorities and with which the Committee agreed. As detailed in the report, the categorisation is significant in that it is a basis for determining which functions should be performed by authorities, the independence required by authorities in particular categories and it also provides a structure within which financial accountability can be determined. In terms of financial accountability, the Committee generally concurs with proposals of the joint working party, which comprised the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General 's Office, that guidelines be provided for authority financial reporting. To enable the implementation of the guidelines, once finalised, the Committee recommends that they form part of an annual reports Act.

The introduction of an annual reports Act is another major recommendation contained in earlier reports of the Senate Finance and Government Operations Committee and the fifth report provides greater detail as to the contents of the proposed Act. Some of the inclusions in the annual reports Act are: Proposed guidelines as to financial statements as set out in the joint working party report; time limits for reporting by commercial authorities of six months and for other authorities three months; interim reports should be presented when it becomes clear that a full report cannot be presented in the recommended time period; that authorities not create subsidiaries with powers wider than their own; that ministerial approval be obtained prior to the creation of authorities; the same auditor should audit both the parents' and subsidiaries' accounts; and that prior to the creation of overseas subsidiaries to the authority should obtain prior ministerial approval and the Parliament must have knowledge of the proposal to create the subsidiary.

In addition, the Committee has examined in detail the relationship between Ministers and authorities taking into account both the legal and the practical relationships which do and should exist. In particular the Committee has examined the question of ministerial responsibility in relation to authorities and the resultant effect that this can have on an authority's independence. The Committee recommends that where it is appropriate for the Minister to have any power of direction over an authority, the Minister should have a general power of direction with authorities maintaining a written record of directions so given and the Minister tabling them within six sitting days of their being made. In considering the relationship between Ministers and authorities, the Committee has also set out the role of the departments in terms of the authorities administered by their particular Minister of state. In particular the role of departmental members on authority boards is questioned and recommendations made that they should be non-voting members, with full access to information and documents, so as to avoid any question of conflict of interest.

The report also examines the economic impact and financial behaviour of authorities. The Committee considers this aspect of such importance that it is currently the subject of a separate major inquiry which will be reported on to the Senate in the new year. Reference is made to the question of sunset legislation. The Committee concludes that the review component of sunset is indeed essential but that this review could be achieved by other more cost- effective means. The experience of the limitations and failures of the United States of America sunset review system was in the mind of the Committee. Other matters referred to in the Committee's fifth report concern staffing of authorities and Australian Capital Territory authorities.

The Committee's sixth report continues our case study approach to the examination of particular Commonwealth statutory authorities. This report contains 15 individual reports which have been prepared by the Committee between November 1981 and August 1982. Six of these reports have been presented to the Senate previously but are reprinted in this report because they form an important part of the endeavour of this Committee to identify and develop the problems and suggested solutions to the problems revealed. I do not propose to detail the particular matters in regard to annual reports and other matters raised in this sixth report as essentially the solution lies in the recommendations contained in the fifth report. The provisions of our proposed annual reports Act will go a long way toward resolving the particular problems raised.

However, I would like to comment on two matters of significance. The Committee' s report on the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 resulted in the Bill being withdrawn as the service to which the charge applied was found to be not required by the honey industry or overseas importers of honey. The Committee has also reported on the 1978-79 and 1979-80 annual reports of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority and it is with some concern that I report to the Senate that the Committee has found it necessary to censure board members for permitting the sequence of events constituting the saga set out in the report and their apparent unwillingness to resolve their problems despite the specific legislative provisions obligating them to do so.

In tabling the reports I wish to acknowledge the cost effectiveness of the new system of word processing introduced by the Committee secretariat for printing reports which has resulted in the fifth and sixth reports being printed within 2 weeks rather than the usual 2 months. I commend the reports to the Senate. I take the opportunity on behalf of the members of the Committee to acknowledge the work that has been done by the Committee secretariat and the very considerable contribution which it has made. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the reports. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Government Finance and Operations but I was not at the time a lot of the evidence was taken which led to the drafting of the fifth report. I must say I am enthusiastic about much of what is contained in it. I believe that the report will make a major contribution to public administration in this country although we acknowledge that much more work has to be done on many aspects of the administration of statutory authorities covered in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Rae gave a rough outline of the chapters in the fifth report. He mentioned that there was a categorised list of authorities. I think that this is a very useful document in that it sets out the many authorities of the Commonwealth. However, I think in some cases the categorisation is unsatisfactory in that we have much more refining to do. This points to an important aspect of the whole study of statutory authorities. I think that one cannot generalise too much about statutory authorities. One can make comments about the need for much more ministerial responsibility and accountability of authorities through their Ministers to the Parliament and the need for Ministers to be able to give directions and to have them carried through. But if one says that in too generalised a fashion one can easily be pulled up in relation to certain authorities where that would not be expected to apply. I refer to authorities such as courts and tribunals and the Australian Broadcasting Commission where most of us would say there has to be a high degree of independence about things like programming. So we have to be careful about generalising. Of course, the sorts of generalised comments that are often made about the need for accountability of business authorities are very true.

The list of statutory authorities has been expanded quite a lot because it includes Public Service officers who happen to be subject to an Act of Parliament passed in relation to their duties and responsibilities. For instance , the Director-General of Social Security is listed as a statutory authority. Yet, of course, he is head of the Department of Social Security. It just happens that the Parliament has passed legislation to prescribe certain of the activities of that office.

I think that this report will be very useful for the Labor Government which will doubtless come into office next year, or sooner if Malcolm Fraser gets a sudden rush of blood to the head before the end of this year. I think much of what is in the report reflects the thinking of the Australian Labor Party about the way in which Government ought to deal with statutory authorities under its control and the activities of Ministers in relation to statutory authorities.

Another aspect of the fifth report that I highlight is the issue of the relationship between Ministers and authorities, and the power of direction. Again, as I have mentioned, it does not apply to all statutory authorities, only the relevant ones. In the conclusions on page 67, the report states:

We consider that the legislative provisions governing the ministerial power of direction over local authorities are in need of change to ensure the accountability to the Parliament of those responsible for authorities' actions.
The Committee considers that where it is appropriate to have any power of direction then the minister should have a general power of direction in terms such as:
'The Corporation shall comply with any directions given to it by the minister with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers' .
That section of the conclusion continues:

Difficulties are caused by giving ministers power over specific matters only. The implication in specifying these matters is that the minister has no power of direction over other matters. A general power of direction in the above term should form part of the Annual Reports Act.

The major advantage of giving ministers a general power of direction would be to remove any doubts about the implementation by authorities of government policy or guidelines. Ministers would always have the power to direct authorities to follow policies or guidelines, and authorities could expect to be thereby fully and accurately informed of their content, unlike the uncertainty which has arisen in the past.

But, as the Committee goes on to say, the important thing about ministerial directions is that they be published. If a Minister instructs an authority to do something, he should not be able to shelter behind the eventual action of the authority by saying that it was that authority's action. It should be clear that it was as a result of a specific direction from a Minister. The report discusses the way in which Ministers ought to provide direction in writing, the way in which the authority ought to publish those directions in its annual report, and the way in which a Minister ought to table in the Parliament in appropriate circumstances the direction so that, in those cases where it would be far too late for the public to be aware of the direction to wait for the annual report, the time limits can be observed.

Amongst the many matters covered in the fifth report I highlight also chapter 9 about the financial behaviour of business and similar authorities. I point to the discussion on page 94 about the payment of Commonwealth and State taxes and charges. Of course, this applies especially to business authorities. Business authorities would be better able to show their real costs and benefits if the relevant local or State government taxes and charges were paid. There is a very uneven implementation of this. Some authorities, such as Qantas Airways Limited, Trans Australia Airlines and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, are subject to income tax. Others, such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post are not. There is an uneven application of State taxes and charges and local government rates though, of course, we need to note that some authorities in appropriate cases make ex-gratia payments for those rates even when they are not obliged to pay them.

I should like to make one or two comments about the sixth report which, as Senator Peter Rae has said, covers reports on individual matters referred by the Senate to the Finance and Government Operations Committee. The outstanding feature of the report is that it shows such a wide range of authorities as having problems-problems which have been referred to the Committee. These range from the National Gallery to the Special Broadcasting Service, the Overseas Property Bureau, payments to an individual supposedly to advertise Australia overseas, the administration of the Cocos and Christmas Islands and the fishing industry. I suppose that if there is one theme that emerges it is the possibility of lack of communication in the administration of some authorities and in regard to some payments by departments.

In chapter 11 we read of the payments to Ken Warby of Spirit of Australia fame. It highlights some particularly poor ministerial administration by certain former Ministers of this Government and is worthy of attention.

Another example was provided by the Cocos Islands-Christmas Island administration, which again showed the benefit of the activities of the Finance and Government Operations Committee in bringing the authorities together and thereby relatively quickly solving problems that had continued for some time, apparently because of mere lack of communication. Much of the Committee's work is concerned with considering the tardiness of authorities in presenting annual reports. That appears to have some effect because certain authorities seem to be doing more to get their reports in on time. One of the key matters upon which the Committee is insisting is appreciation of the fact that annual reports are important but it is particularly important that they be presented early or they become of purely archival value only. In conclusion, I pay tribute to the staff of the Committee and the enthusiasm of the Chairman. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to provide bounty assistance to the production in Australia of certain fresh berry fruits used for processing.

The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's acceptance of a recommendation by the Industries Assistance Commission in its Report No. 276 of 24 August 1981 entitled 'Fruit and Fruit Products'. The report covered a wide range of miscellaneous processed fruit products and fresh and processed passionfruit and berry fruits. The Government's decision on that report was announced on 21 April 1982.

The Government accepted the IAC's views that assistance in the form of a bounty rather than a tariff would be more appropriate in this case. A tariff on imports would have the effect of increasing the cost of locally produced jam and juice products using imported berry fruit and reduce the competitiveness of those jams and juices against imports. Furthermore a tariff was considered not to be an efficient means of assisting producers of berry fruits.

The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable at the rate of $100 per tonne of commercially cultivated fresh fruit provided to processors of the fruit. The bounty is to be paid directly to the growers of the fruit and bounty payments will be based on information provided in regular returns to be furnished by the processors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for taking the time of the Senate, particularly on an occasion on which we have Estimates committee hearings. I am always reluctant to do it in any case. Unfortunately, however, I was unable to put a question during Question Time this morning and I must raise the matter that I would have raised at that time. I shall try to be as brief as possible. The background is that the Commonwealth Electoral Office in the Northern Territory is refusing to supply candidates with enrolment cards to enable them to go out and enrol people, to get them on the electoral roll. The question that I would have put this morning was in two parts. Firstly, who made the decision? Was it the Commonwealth Electoral Office or was it a ministerial or a Government decision? The second half of the question would have asked the Minister whether he would ensure that candidates would have unlimited supplies of enrolment cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is fair to say that parties of all political colours have carried out enrolment drives in their own particular areas. It is an important part of the campaigning activities of all candidates. When they go door knocking , if they knock on the door of a person who is not enrolled, they ask that person to complete a card, it is signed, and they take it back. I think that all of us who have campaigned at any time will know the advantage in that sort of situation. In the Northern Territory it is particularly important when those of us who are candidates or those of us who are in Parliament at present go to outlying, remote areas, either where Aboriginal people live or where there are stations with both Aboriginal and white populations.

It would seem to me that 100 per cent enrolment is what we are all about. It is the intention of all of us-the Commonwealth Electoral Office, politicians and the population generally-to try to get 100 per cent enrolment of all people. There should be no limitation or restriction whatsoever on enrolment. I am not suggesting that there is anything like the shocking situation that developed in Western Australia a couple of years ago; rather, that we are simply working towards that goal.

There are two possible responses: Firstly, that the Commonwealth office is doing the job, therefore we do not have to do it; and secondly, that in some way it is undesirable to have party involvement in enrolment. On the first possible response, let me say that I appreciate the work that the Commonwealth office is doing, particularly in the Aboriginal areas. I was involved in that before I came into this place, giving assistance from the Department of Education. I commend that office for its work. Nevertheless, why restrict it simply to that office? After all, if the Commonwealth Electoral Office misses some of those who ought to be enrolled, let that group that is missed out be picked up by the candidate. The office is obviously short of staff. All Commonwealth offices are short of staff at present, particularly in remote areas. The office is short of staff who have the expertise to deal with Aboriginal people, so I think that we can assist them in this way.

The second possible response is that there is something undesirable in candidates enrolling people. I reject that. I reject as nonsense any suggestion that any influence is exerted on people simply because one encourages them to fill out an enrolment card. Our method of balloting in Australia, our secret ballot, covers this. There is no possibility that simply because one gets a person on the electoral roll he will necessarily vote for one. Many of us feel that often when doing this work we may be getting votes for our opposite numbers . This does not concern me at all and I am sure that it does not concern anyone who travels around.

Our goal is to get 100 per cent enrolment. I feel that on election campaign is the ideal time to do so. The climate is right. We are talking to people about political matters. We can raise the subject of whether their names are on the electoral roll. If they say they are not, it is an ideal time to take out the card, get it filled in and signed and to take it back to the electoral office for processing. I remind the Minister that this work is done voluntarily and it assists the office to achieve the goal of having 100 per cent of all Australians registered on the roll. Rather than prolong the adjournment debate, I call on the Minister to instruct the Commonwealth Electoral Office to make sure that candidates, at least, are supplied with unlimited access to enrolment cards so that they may assist in this goal of enrolment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate I wish to make some brief comments on the Press coverage of the debate and vote yesterday afternoon on the motion to discuss a matter of urgency on South West Tasmania moved by Senator Chipp. I do not want to rehash the debate of yesterday or to repeat everything I said in my speech. SPEECH.PARA: I am always loath to complain about what appears to be unfair Press coverage and I very rarely do it. But it struck me that in this case the coverage was incomplete. This applied particularly to the Tasmanian papers, which I assume got the Australian Associated Press report of the matter, and also Helen O'Neil' s report on PM last night. The interpretation in those reports was that the reason the Government and the Opposition senators voted against taking a vote on the original motion was that they were scared of people crossing the floor. The original motion was along the lines of stated ALP policy, but the reason we did not want a vote on the motion was that the Senate Select Committee on which Senator Chipp and Opposition senators were serving was in existence. If the Opposition had moved such a motion on some other issue while that issue was before a committee we would have been shot down in flames by everyone concerned and accused of being rude to the Senate; it would be claimed to be part of our downgrading its role, opposing its powers and that sort of thing.
