He got up here today quietly during the adjournment debate and said: 'Obviously Senator Chipp had briefed the Press on his interpretation of events'. I categorically deny that allegation. No member of the Press knew of my intentions, knew what I was going to say or knew what my tactics were until after the event at about six o'clock when I simply gave copies of my speech to members of the Press and agreed to an interview with one journalist.

SPEECH.PARA: I am rather curious at the so-called outrage of Senator Coates and other members of the Australian Labor Party. Let me cite a couple of statistics. Since the Government lost control of the Senate, on 18 out of 21 Wednesdays-that is the day the proceedings of the Senate are broadcast-the Australian Labor Party has raised matters of public importance or urgency motions. It has had those opportunities by the grace, I suggest, of the Government, which could easily have got in before the Labor Party and raised matters of public importance or urgency motions. That course is open to any member of the Government. As a matter of courtesy, the Government has allowed the Labor Party to raise that number of matters. The Australian Democrats could have broken agreements and could have sneaked into the President's chamber at one minute past midnight in an endeavour to raise such matters.

If Senator Coates is whingeing about not having a fair go, let him look at the statistics. On 18 out of 21 occasions, the Australian Labor Party has had the floor when the Senate proceedings have been broadcast on a Wednesday. The Government has raised such matters on two occasions and the Australian Democrats only on one occasion since the Government lost control of the Senate. Senator Coates talked about lack of consultation but I point out that it was only one week ago, last Thursday, when a member of his own party put down in this chamber a matter of urgency without consulting the Australian Democrats, and without telling us that it was a matter of urgency instead of a matter of public importance. I think it is absolute humbug for him to get up here now and say that we owed it to somebody to tell some other political party about our intentions. I do not wish to canvass the matter as Senator Coates did today. I thought more of him and I thought he would have at least paid me the courtesy of telling me that he intended to raise this matter in the adjournment debate. Whatever he says, the fact remains that yesterday an opportunity was open to him to force this Senate to vote on an issue. He chose to deny the Senate that opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should like to make it clear to Senator Chipp that the point of my remarks today was the failure of the Press to refer to the existence of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. The reference to him was a secondary reference, apart from the fact that it was very much a last minute decision on my part to rise in the adjournment debate. I should like also to point out in relation to Senator Chipp's remarks that I made no suggestion that the Australian Democrats were not entitled to raise a matter of public importance. There was no reference whatsoever to that. Of course they are entitled to raise their fair share of matters of public importance. In saying that there ought to have been consultation, I did not say that they had an obligation to consult other than in relation to the South West Tasmania issue . My point was that, to ensure that the issue was dealt with in an appropriate way, it was my opinion that it would have been preferable for consultation to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — Briefly, I wish to foreshadow a matter that I will raise and to give the Senate notice of an intention. I believe that it would be desirable if one of the Senate committees were to consider the following terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact in Australia upon labour and labour related costs including wage and employment agreements of various forms of protection arising from:
(a) customs tariffs and quotas
(b) natural protection of an industry from international competition, for example, the building industry
(c) other forms of imposed or natural protection from international competition .

I do not think that I need to elaborate in detail as to why I believe it would be of value to the whole of Australia for some work to be done by a Senate committee in relation to these questions. I believe that the public debate in relation to them is not necessarily well-informed. There are many matters which affect the economy and the management of the economy of Australia which are not just industrial matters. This matter is not raised for the purpose of having a mud-slinging exercise but rather to try to find out what is the situation in relation to protection and what is the impact. The National Farmers Federation and other organisations continually express their concern. The Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd and others have expressed their concern. The Industries Assistance Commission has at times had to deal with the matter. But I do not believe that a parliamentary committee has ever conducted the type of inquiry which I think could help the consideration of the matter and the application of principles in relation to these questions.

I therefore wanted to speak very briefly to indicate to the Senate that in the future I will be raising this matter formally as a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, possibly even to the same committee which has been looking at the questions involving the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and the Coburg Clothing Factory, or to some other committee. Part of the reason I raise this matter in this way is to invite some thought on the part of honourable senators as to which would be the most appropriate way that this objective could be achieved. I thank the Senate for the opportunity of raising this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which I first raised in this chamber by way of a question on Tuesday, 24 August. I put a question in two parts to Senator Chaney in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I referred to the very serious problem which is now occurring in the timber industry in the south-east of South Australia. I asked him what the Government or what Mr Lynch, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, was doing to try to eliminate this problem. I pointed out to the Minister that the problem was being created by imports of cheap New Zealand timber in particular and of some from the United States of America. I asked my question and the Minister in part of his answer said that Mr Lynch had met also with representatives of the South East Trades and Labour Council of South Australia. I knew that because I arranged the deputation of the representatives of the South East Trades and Labour Council to meet with Mr Lynch in Melbourne. I accompanied those representatives to Melbourne to have talks with the Minister. While we were there the Minister said that he would be making a statement within a week or so as to whether there would be a reference to the Temporary Assistance Authority on whether any dumping was taking place, but he did not make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney was not able to inform me about what was happening except to say that some representatives of his Department were going to carry out further talks with representatives of the equivalent departments in New Zealand. I accepted that but I was very surprised when I picked up the Hansard of Thursday, 26 August and saw a very detailed statement, plus a document which was incorporated, by the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, who was representing Mr Lynch, which obviously was in answer to a Dorothy Dix question from the Federal member for Barker, Mr Porter. I can only assume that having read the Hansard of Tuesday he was prompted to take some action about the problem in the south-east of South Australia because to my mind that is the first time he has gone public about the problem which exists in the south-east. He was able to get a very detailed answer-much more detailed than I was able to get. Obviously Senator Chaney was just as aware of the matter as Mr Hodgman because when we analyse the two answers we see that the answer which I received from Senator Chaney on the Tuesday was in exactly the same words as Mr Hodgman's answer in the House of Representatives. Mr Hodgman was even pulled up by the Speaker because he was going on for too long with his answer. There were a couple of interjections. Mr Hurford said:
More talks! What is he doing about it?
He was referring to Mr Lynch. Prior to that he had said by way of interjection:
What is he doing about it?

Later my colleague Mr Morris, the honourable member for Shortland, raised a point of order. Arising out of that Mr Hodgman had incorporated in Hansard a document. So it would appear that it was quite obvious that the Government was prepared to give more details of what Mr Lynch was doing to the member for Barker even though he was two days behind me in asking the question. I have had some detailed involvement in the problem which exists down there and it concerns me. I hope that, in future when I ask questions, if the Government has the information to hand it will at least give it to me when I am up on my feet first and not keep it until the honourable member for Barker reads the Hansard, sees what I have been trying to do for the people and then comes in on the grouter, as the saying goes. The other part of the question about which I am most concerned and which I raised on that occasion has to do with the proposed closure of the cellulose mill at Millicent. On that day I asked Senator Chaney:

Has the Government received any representation from the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, for assistance in preventing the cellulose paper mill at Millicent from closing, with the resultant loss of more than 300 jobs? If no representation has been received, will the Minister take immediate action to ascertain what is required to prevent the closure from taking place?
I had to ask a supplementary question and remind Senator Chaney that he had not answered. He said:
I have no information in my brief on that matter--
That is, the cellulose mill-
. . . I will have to check that point and let Senator McLaren have a further reply.

More than three weeks have now gone by and I have not received any information from Senator Chaney as to whether the South Australian Liberal Premier, Mr Tonkin, has done anything to try to keep that industry in the south-east. I was very disturbed to read in the Adelaide Advertiser of Wednesday, 15 September 1982, under the heading '175 SE jobs may go, says union', an article written by an industrial reporter called Michael Grealy which stated:
A paper-manufacturing plant near Millicent employing 175 workers may be closed, according to the major union at the plant.
The State president of the Pulp and Papermakers' Federation, Mr F. J. Haggis, said yesterday unions had been called to a meeting in Melbourne today to hear a decision on the plant's future.
The article continued:
Mr Haggis said that since then APM had expanded its plants interstate but ' virtually nothing has happened here'.
He went on further to say:
Local quality could not match the product made interstate, where the company had installed modern machinery.

That is what concerns me. We have a government in South Australia which was elected on a promise, among others, to stop the job rot and to get industry on its feet. Its claim at the time, that industry was lagging in South Australia under the then Labor Government, has been proved to be untrue by what has happened in the last three years.

I am concerned about the statement of Mr Haggis that local quality could not match the product made interstate where the company had installed modern machinery. I would have thought that if the Tonkin Government was concerned about retaining people-and I pointed out that South Australia had slipped behind Western Australia in terms of population when I spoke in this place during the tabling of papers-it would have taken some action to assist this industry, if it needed financial assistance, to upgrade its machinery so that South Australia could compete with Victoria. I would have thought Mr Tonkin would have been very interested in this matter and that perhaps Mr Porter would have acquainted him with the problem in view of the fact that they both belong to the same party. I have no doubt that the ability of the work force in the south-east of South Australia is equal to any. The article points out that members of the work force have been in the industry for a long time. It states:
The average age of workers at the plant now was 48 and their average service was 16.5 years.

So the workers have had long experience in that industry in the south-east. However, it seems as though the industry is now to close as I predicted over three weeks ago in this place when I asked the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) what the South Australian Government had done to try to prevent this happening. It is quite obvious that the South Australian Government did nothing because Senator Chaney has not replied. I am wondering what is going to happen to the 175 people employed directly in the cellulose mill. If the mill closes down the figure of 300 I used, which was given to me by responsible people in the south-east, could be even greater because the closure would affect log fellers and a whole host of people such as those engaged in transport associated with the industry. When we lump that on top of the fact that imported timber from New Zealand and America has caused many of the mills in the south- east to go to a four-day week or a nine-day fortnight and the retrenchment of 75 workers following the closure of the Sapfor mill, we find that we have a very serious problem in the south-east. However, this problem does not exist only in the south-east. The article to which I am referring bears out the fact that Mr Tonkin is not doing the job he was elected to do and in respect of which he criticised the Labor Party. The article refers to other developments. It states:
United Trades and Labor Council industrial officer Mr R. L. Felmingham said about 2000 jobs had been lost in the SA manufacturing industry this year.
The State secretary of the Transport Workers' Union, Mr K. M. Cys, said 111 TWU members had lost their jobs in SA recently, most in August.
About 45 people are expected to be retrenched by Perry Engineering Co. Ltd, at Mile End.
Mr Felmingham said a survey of affiliated unions in manufacturing industry showed a loss of 1417 jobs--
He is talking about South Australia-
since January.
The workers had been retrenched, made redundant or had accepted early retirement.
The survey of 18 companies showed 279 fewer jobs at Kelvinator Australia Ltd, 330 at General Motors-Holdens Ltd, 105 at ATCO, 125 at BHP, 75 at Sapfor Timber Mills--
That is the industry about which I have been talking-
47 at Gerard Industries, 50 at Kenwood, 95 at Tubemakers, 100 at NEI Engineering and 100 at Mount Barker tannery.

Of course, living near the Mount Barker tannery I know that this enterprise has closed down and that the land is being sold. When we were in government I was able to get over a quarter of a million dollars to assist that industry, firstly through Mr Enderby when he was the responsible Minister and later through Senator James McClelland, who is now Mr Justice McClelland. Now, following the election of a Liberal Government in Canberra and a State Liberal Government in South Australia that industry has gone-it has been closed down and the property is being sold. One can go on and on. It is a whole sorry story about what is happening not just federally but particularly in South Australia. Governments, both Federal and State, appear to be closing their eyes to the problems of industries which are closing down and workers who are having to go on the dole.

I am disturbed that I have not had an answer, particularly from Senator Chaney. I do not blame him. He probably tried to get answers from those departments that he represents. But I have not had an answer. I hope that when we return here next week Senator Chaney or somebody responsible can put down an answer and in particular can tell us what Mr Tonkin is doing, if he is doing anything, to keep these industries in South Australia. As I said earlier in the debate on the Grants Commission report, the population of South Australia has now slipped behind that of Western Australia. That State is in diabolical trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I raise matters in the Senate I do not raise what I consider are irrelevant issues. Unless a matter is relevant I do not speak about it. On Tuesday evening I spoke in the adjournment debate in this place. The matter I spoke of was not a world shattering matter but it was of some importance and I think of some relevance. Before I spoke, I indicated through the Whips that I did not really expect a reply from the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), as I do not expect a reply from the Minister to what I am saying now. However, I did receive a reply from the Minister that night. But it was a petty and pompous reply. I received it from the Minister for Education. The reply was not fitting for the type of item that I raised and it was not the type of reply that I would expect from a responsible Minister. This afternoon I invite the Minister for Education to read the Hansard record of what I said on that day. If he does, I am sure that he will soon see that his comments and his sarcasm on Tuesday evening were quite misplaced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Some six honourable senators have spoken in this adjournment debate. I make some brief comments. Senator Robertson raised the question of an apparent denial by the Australian Electoral Office in the Northern Territory-in Darwin I think-to supply to candidates, or presumably others, quantities of enrolment cards. My comments are informal. I have a vague recollection of this matter having risen under my gaze at some stage in the last year or two and of some restriction having been imposed. The restriction was decided upon, as I understood it, by the Australian Electoral Office. I think primarily it was an attempt to stop an unlimited supply of enrolment cards. I can understand that, and I think Senator Robertson would. There could be unreasonable requests and, again from my memory, I think this has been evidenced in requests for some thousands of cards. My reaction was to say that, as I understood it, a right exists for any citizen to obtain electoral cards and to invite others to do so if they have not enrolled. I understood it had been settled on the basis that reasonableness would prevail. I will ask that Senator Robertson's remarks be referred. If there is more to add to what I have said, I will have it added. In any case, if my recollection is right, I will invite the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) to have discussions with the Australian Electoral Office to ensure that cards are available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —An hour or so ago Senator Chipp was speaking in the Senate and he drew attention in a general way to the state of confusion in which the Government finds itself, partly because of the many reefs and shoals that seem to beset it at the moment-largely of its own making, I might say-but also I believe because of a certain lack of will, a lack of ability, by the Government to perceive what the problems of the country are and to try to do something about them.

SPEECH.PARA: In this first reading debate on the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1982 I want to draw attention to a subject I have mentioned before and which I think is very important; that is, the close association between the energy problems of the country and its unemployment problems. In other words, I wish basically to bring forward the thesis that if unemployment is to be controlled it will not be done by encouraging people to be trained in industries and occupations which are already overcrowded; it will be done by looking at new areas of activity and industry which are to the public benefit and, by doing that, making work for some of the people who are at present unemployed. this is not an original idea; it is being done in so many countries overseas that it worries me intensely that the Government of Australia has not yet got around to considering it as a serious proposition. I suggest that the Government, if it really wants to get back the goodwill of the people of Australia and to re- establish some faith in the processes of Government, should get to work on something like that, it should look at what is going on overseas, read the lessons and do something which would indeed-this has been proven; it is not just hypothetical-get many thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, of Australians back to work. Indeed, as is happening in some countries, we might even get to the stage where there is virtually a labour shortage. It seems to the Australian Democrats that the Government is seeing the future through a telescope that is well out of focus-a myopic one-and that, as a result, its view is very vague and indistinct. It does not see any of the long term problems of the country and because of that it naturally does not see any solutions.

At the moment we are lulled into a false sense of security by the apparent world glut of petrol. I think all of us who appreciate the situation at all well understand that this will not last. It will be only a matter of a few years before we run out, in spite of the glut in production. The amount of petrol still underground is not increasing; it is diminishing rapidly. Every day that passes reduces the amount of oil that can be taken from our major field in Bass Strait. It is significant that the major rundown in production is only too likely to coincide with a crunch in the world supply situation towards the end of the present decade. If we want to do something about that we must do something now because of the lead times that are required to get that sort of industry into operation. For example, it taes some five years to get a methanol plant into operation. I think it will be much too late if we allow things to drift on until the end of the decade without doing anything about those matters.

The Government is failing lamentably in this whole energy field. It persists, for its inscrutable reasons-I believe they are inscrutable-in involving itself more and more deeply with the discredited, uneconomic and dangerous nuclear power industry which we, of all countries, could very well do without. I think all Australians should be asking themselves what the reasons are. What reasons of money and influence determine this perverse policy of the Government? Why is it so concerned with only that area of energy? Why is it that so much money is being put into that area? The fact is that nuclear energy, and the manufacture of small, dirty atomic bombs of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki type, are very closely associated. Most of the countries now building so-called peaceful reactors-the ones which have not cancelled their orders-want them, not for power but to derive plutonium to make bombs. It is worth once again stressing the point that it is much easier and quicker to breed plutonium in a modern power reactor than it is to breed it in a fast breeder reactor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which countries are you talking about?

—I have a list of them here. They are: Argintina, Libya, Pakistan, South Korea, South Africa and the Phillipines. Every one of them, as the honourable senator knows, is a notable democracy! I am being sardonic, of course -they are not. Every one of them is a repressive and dictatorial regime. It is an open secret-they have admitted it-that virtually their nuclear power structures are there to provide weapons. When they do that we will have a miserable future of regional wars throughout the world, in every area in which these things are used.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates spoke about yesterday's debate on the South West Tasmanian dam. In the amount of media that I was able to see or hear this morning I was struck by the fact that the report zoned into one aspect only-that was a division in this place-and did not deal in any way with the reasons. I believe one can say, at the kindest, that the report was incomplete. Yesterday there was recourse to a fundamental principle of this Senate: It is that from time to time it selects subject matters that it believes need to be examined in detail, refers them to a Senate committee, and then defers debate upon them until it is adequately equipped to undertake it. For example, rightly or wrongly, today the Plant Variety Rights Bill has been referred to a committee as was, some weeks ago, the industrial relations legislation. There is no suggestion that, while that is happening there should be debate, on a motion of urgency or otherwise, on the relevant matters. Whether yesterday the urgency motion, if one draws a fine line , was within Standing Orders, does not matter. What happened was that the substantial majority, virtually all but some five honourable senators in this place, believed that we ought to proceed in the normal manner, bearing in mind that a Senate committee investigating a subject has all of the powers of the Senate. Therefore, we had empowered it to go ahead. It is a pity that it might have been construed that there were goodies and baddies yesterday, that for some reason or other there were baddies on both sides of this chamber opposing five Galahads of this world who wanted to fight for the rights of environmentalists. It may be that that was a public relations goal-who shall say. However, it would be proper if the media saw fit to put the matter into perspective. I do not enter the matter that was the subject of dialogue between Senator Chipp and Senator Coates. It seems to me to be one that is outside ministerial responsiblity. Arrangements made behind doors are matters of domestic concern, they can be sorted out otherwise.

I note that Senator Peter Rae has what he considers to be a subject of considerable importance, relating to industry protection, that he proposes to introduce at some time. I have no doubt that the Senate will give it due consideration.

Senator McLaren raised what he considered was inaction in regard to two questions. As he would expect. I have no basic first-hand knowledge of either. I hope that all Ministers, as a general principle, treat impartially, all questions asked of them, and I believe we do. Apart from the ordinary melodrama of thrust and parry across the chamber, if a question is asked, it is the intention, certainly of the Ministers with whom I am associated, to give a fair answer. We welcome questions on notice, particularly, so that we can do that. I know nothing about the intervention of an earlier answer to another person in another place. I will draw the attention of the Minister to it and to Senator McLaren's comments.

Equally, he has reminded me of a question regarding the cellulose mill at Millicent. I share his view, as would all honourable senators, that the loss of employment in any place, and there certainly, would be a bad thing. I regret that no answer has been given to him so far. I will refer his comments today, and the question, to the appropriate sources and seek an answer.

I am sorry that Senator Colston should have felt it necessary to rise to make the comment that he did. If he feels that he did not receive a satisfactory answer to a particular comment that he made, I will draw that to the attention of the relevant Minister and ask him to peruse Hansard. If the Minister feels then that he needs to comment, he may do so.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a demarcation dispute for a number of years prevented the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Sydney from using electronic news gathering equipment .
(2) Do most capital city commercial stations use these videotape cameras while the ABC continues to use film cameras.
(3) When did this dispute commence.
(4) Has it ended, or is it close to finality.
(5) What was the cost of the equipment involved when it was purchased by the ABC, and when was that purchase made.
(6) Is the equipment now considered to be obsolete.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Australian Broadcasting Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A dispute has existed for a number of years which has prevented the ABC from expanding its use of electronic news gathering equipment. Electronic news gathering equipment has been used in the ABC for some time but its application is being restricted until the demarcation issue over the staffing and operational aspects of the equipment is resolved.

(2) Electronic cameras were used for news gathering by the ABC in Sydney, Canberra, Darwin, Rockhampton, Townsville, before the demarcation dispute commenced and are still used in these centres. In other places the cameras have not replaced film cameras in news gathering but are in use for other purposes and in the electronic field production of programs. Information in relation to electronic news gathering equipment in commercial stations is not readily available.
(3) The current demarcation dispute commenced in 1977.
(4) The dispute appears to be nearing an end.

(5) The total cost of equipment specifically purchased for electronic news gathering is estimated at approximately $1m and although the equipment has been purchased over a number of years, the bulk of its has been acquired in the last two financial years.

(6) The ABC has used electronic news gathering equipment in various forms for approximately 10 years. As old equipment wears out it has been replaced with current generation equipment. No equipment has remained unused in store so long that it is now obsolete.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware that some schoolchildren in the United States gained access illegally to confidential computer records in that country.

(2) My Department uses leased communication lines, not a switched network, which it is understood was used in the case cited. As a consequence unauthorised persons in Australia could not gain access in the same way as the American children did.
(3) Security precautions taken include:
remote terminals can only access authorised information;
remote terminals are locked when not in use;
sensitive data and system data are password protected.
(4) There is very little personal information held in the computer systems of my Department and this is securely protected.
(5) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2010) Senator Elstob asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that as an associate member of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Professor Donald Gibson, whose duties with the Tribunal will cease with the presentation of the Tribunal's report on cable television by 30 June this year, is presently undertaking a two-week trip to a United States of America cable convention in Las Vegas at tribunal expense? Is it further true that the public hearings for the inquiry are complete and that the report is already substantially written? If so, what is the use of this trip and how is it justified?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:

I have discussed the matter with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and have been informed that Professor Donald Gibson, associate member of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for the purposes of the cable television inquiry, did attend the Annual Conference of the National Cable Television Association in Las Vegas between 2 and 5 May 1982 as a representative of the Tribunal. The Tribunal met the costs of Professor Gibson's attendance at the Conference. The Tribunal considered it important that it should be represented at tribunal level at the conference which was attended by representatives from most countries of the world.
I granted an extension of time for submission of the report and Professor Gibson remained an associate member of the Tribunal until the completed report was presented to me.

In addition to his attendance at the conference Professor Gibson had discussions with representatives of the Industry and visited Harvard University , Stanford University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Any cost associated with these additional discussions was met by Professor Gibson.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current staff ceiling imposed on the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC).
(2) To what extent, if any, has this staff ceiling been varied in the last 12 months.
(3) To what extent has the ABC entered into contractual arrangements for the performance of work previously performed by staff on the ABC in order to avoid the difficulties imposed by staff ceilings.
(4) To what extent are ABC announcers and/or film cameramen now employed on short term contracts.
(5) What cost benefit analysis has been conducted on the relative cost of engaging contractors in the areas of cleaning, production work, and any other work formerly performed by ABC staff.
(6) What cuts in television productions will be necessary as a result of the imposition of a 2 per cent staff cut in production crews.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The staff ceiling for 30 June 1982 was 6,143 full time and 79 part time staff. As of 1 July 1982, the Australian Broadcasting Commission is exempt from the staff ceiling provisions.
(2) The staff ceiling for 30 June 1981 was 6,202 full time and 81 part time staff.

(3) In technical areas, the normal staff has been augmented from time to time by temporary staff and staff supplied by contractors, to meet peak loads during work on colour television conversion, up-grading of radio studios in regional areas and for special projects such as the Commonwealth Games.
Contract cleaning, security, plumbing and electrical services have been used where possible so that available staff resources could be concentrated in the program production areas.
(4) No ABC announcers or film cameramen are employed on short term contacts. Where contract staff in these areas are used they are engaged on renewable contracts of at least 12 months.
(5) Contract cleaning has been widely utilised in the ABC since the mid-1950's and the extent of any prior costing or consultation with other authorities is not known.

The rates paid are checked from time to time against those approved by the Department of Administrative Services for the Commonwealth Government service and are considered to be broadly cost effective. Recent cost analyses related to plumbing, electrical and security services have tended to favour provisions of these services by ABC staff.

(6) There were no cuts in television production in 1981-82 as a result of the 1 per cent reduction in staff ceiling in that year. In the latter part of the 1981 -82 financial year a reduction in planned television production did take place but this was due to the need to reduce planned expenditure to meet part of wage and salary increases which had occurred during the year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Army Reserve have a display at the 1982 Brisbane Exhibition; if so, when was the display moved and if that was before the conclusion of the exhibition, why was it dismantled early.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Army Reserve display was manned from 9.00 a.m. to 11.00 p.m. daily except on the final day of the Exhibition. It was closed at 4 p.m. on that day because of the need for the Army Reserve soldiers who had manned it to complete all administrative tasks before the following Monday when they were required to resume their civil employment. It was not possible for the power supply to be dismantled on Sunday; hence the need for early closure.
